author: Valens_Research
body:
Sounds very close to a report my firm writes for investment managers every month.

The biggest difference is rather than buying momentum in terms of price (which also has great academic support as a factor), we are looking for longer-term solutions for clients, so focus on business growth measured by asset growth.

We also follow a scorecard approach, scoring on a company’s ROA, asset growth, and P/E, rather than just screening alone. We’ve seen that using this scorecard actually works in the long-run. The screen of the top 50 names measured by the Quality, Growth, and Valuation (QGV) scorecard has outperformed the market over the last twenty years. It highlights the value of looking at these kinds of metrics when doing idea generation - they can provide powerful signals.

I can’t give out the full 50, but wanted to share the top 5 from the most recent month:

Company Name|Ticker|ROA|Asset Growth|Earnings Yield
:--|:--|:--:|:--:|:--:
Texas Pacific Land Trust|TPL|139%|94%|7.0%
Prestige Consumer Healthcare|PBH|46%|192%|6.6%
Federated Hermes|FHI|66%|29%|10.6%
CommScope|COMM|49%|42%|7.0%
Fiserv|FISV|86%|129%|4.5%

The one important thing to point out on the above is that our firm is focused on accounting adjustments, and cleaning up bad traditional accounting under GAAP (listen to anything Buffett, Klarman, etc. have to say on the matter…) so the factors we look at are different than what is found on something like Yahoo Finance. I just wanted to point that out since the numbers above won’t quite match something from Bloomberg etc.

These names are also less covered (or at least some are less covered) than the traditional names one sees as hot stocks today.

Great idea to start having discussions about how to find great undiscovered names, and what screens/ratios/scorecards/factors are the best for finding alpha.
